intro: Dichocarpum ohwianum, commonly known as the Himalayan yew, is a deciduous shrub native to the mountainous regions of Asia. It belongs to the family Berberidaceae and is characterized by its woody stems and alternate, compound leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in catkins, followed by red, berry-like fruits. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found at high altitudes in forests and rocky areas. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
